poem:
"Strings on Eastcastle Street"

Oxford Street, rocker's delight, 
Nestled in the city's bright night -
Open the door in a red-coated box,
Strum out the hours on Gibson's clocks.

Beneath the west end's siren call
Plays out a tune that's heard by all.
For Davies and Page, the secret afar,
Resides in a guitar store with a hidden bar.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Guitar maker Gibson opens store off London’s Oxford Street Gibson, the Nashville guitar maker beloved by Jimmy Page to Ray Davies, is opening its first big store outside the US just off London’s Oxford Street, where VIP visitors will be ushered into a secret bar accessed via a door hidden in a red phone box. Opening to the public on Saturday, the 4,500 sq ft (420 sq metres) of space on Eastcastle Street is within". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Guitar maker Gibson opens store off London’s Oxford Street Gibson, the Nashville guitar maker beloved by Jimmy Page to Ray Davies, is opening its first big store outside the US just off London’s Oxford Street, where VIP visitors will be ushered into a secret bar accessed via a door hidden in a red phone box. Opening to the public on Saturday, the 4,500 sq ft (420 sq metres) of space on Eastcastle Street is within
